items.text: It must depend on how large the store is, how many bottles they accept, how busy the area is and how many customers frequent there. If the store has a parking lot, more bottles could be returned as people don’t carry them by themselves. Also, if the machine accepts crates and how large the store's range of drinks and cans is. I would look into how many bottles can be accepted per customer, calculate a daily average and yearly average.

On an average day, I could imagine 3500 bottles to be returned. "Several" is quite unclear, so I assumed about 3 machines. Also, the time elderly people need or people not confident with these machines need has to be factored in. So if every person takes about a minute per two bottles and lines form, I could imagine this being a possible number. This doesn't factor in "rush hours" for these machines though, and several other factors, as mentioned, are disregarded.

Der Automat kann beim Einscannen zählen, wie viele Flaschen abgegeben werden. Am Ende des Tages werden die einzelnen Automaten zusammengezählt und man bekommt die gesamte Menge der abgegebenen Flaschen pro Tag. Das macht man mehrere Tage oder Wochen und rechnet dann den Durchschnittswert aus.
If everyone has 5 bottles and there are around 100 people per day, 500.

To estimate the average number of deposit bottles returned to the supermarket each day, we need to consider its size and location, as busier supermarkets in urban areas typically see more returns. The daily customer traffic plays a critical role; for instance, a supermarket receiving about 1,000 customers daily could serve as a baseline. Furthermore, it’s essential to gauge how many bottles each customer might return; this can vary widely based on individual habits, with an estimated average around 3 bottles per customer. Multiplying the number of customers by the average bottles returned gives us a rough estimate—1,000 customers returning 3 bottles each results in approximately 3,000 bottles per day. Seasonal factors and promotions may also influence these numbers, especially during busy periods like holidays. Moreover, customer recycling habits and awareness can impact return rates significantly. If more data is available, such as historical return rates or specific customer behavior insights, it could further refine this estimate for accuracy.
6 bottles per person on average. Average time spent on machine: 2 minutes. 30 persons per hour. 360 persons per day. 360x6=2160. 2160 bottles per day.

I think about 420-550 deposit bottles are returned per day. I usually buy 9 bottles I need to deposit per week, a family may have 18, so I averaged for 12 since I think I’m on the higher end. I usually return all 9 at once, once a week. If there is a queue, I’m thinking 2-4 people per hour, averaging 2. So at most 12x12x4=576 and 12x12x3=432. So a range of 420-550.
Ich gehe mal davon aus, dass der Supermarkt 14 h geöffnet hat (von 8-22 Uhr) und pro Stunde werden circa 55 Flaschen zurückgegeben. Das bedeutet, dass circa 770 Flaschen pro Tag zurückgegeben werden.
The store is open from 8am till 8pm I assume. I also assume that on average 25 bottles are returned by the hour, which means that 400 bottles are returned by day.

The exact answer cannot be provided, since the input information is incomplete. There is no data on the size of the supermarket, the number of bottle return machines and the variance in the number of bottles and the size of the queues.
My answer is that it should be roughly 100 bottles.

I would estimate that there are on average 50 customers at any given time in the store. Because most times people visit, they don't bring deposit bottles and instead tend to collect them to bring them all at once for ease, I'd estimate that one out of 50 visitors brings deposit bottles, maybe around 20 bottles. So if the supermarket is opened 7-21, that is 14 hours. Estimating people take 30 min in the store, 100 visit every hour and so 40 bottles are brought in every hour, so in one day I would estimate 40 x 14 is 560 deposit bottles returned.
